repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: The collection contains corrected manuscripts and copies of seven plays in English on theater, dance, and German literature.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Walter Sorrel was born in 1894. Sorel was known as a New York dance critic for the Providence Journal. Sorrel wrote over 35 books about dance and other art forms. Sorrel lived in Manhattan, New York and Zurich, Germany. Sorrel died at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York, New York on February 21, 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains corrected manuscripts and copies of seven plays in English on theater, dance, and German literature.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is unprocessed and is likely disorganized. Individual items may be difficult to find.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted because it is unprocessed. Portions of the collection may contain recent administrative records and/or personally identifiable information. While it is likely that portions of the collection may be viewed, access must be managed by an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of copyright. Whenever possible, the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives will provide information about copyright owners and other restrictions, but the legal determination ultimately rests with the researcher. Requests for permission to publish material from this collection should be discussed with the Head of Special Collections and Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows: Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Walter Sorrel Papers, Undated. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Sorrel Papers).
